info.title: Objective-C 2.0 and Cocoa
info.description: Objective-C is a superset of C, it is easy to mix C and even C++ into Cocoa applications. Cocoa is Apple's native object-oriented application programming interface (API) for the OS X operating system. This KEEMI catalog is aimed at developers who have already build an application using Objective-C and Cocoa (or Cocoa Touch) and want to accelerate their daily work with the essentials in mind.

question.name: dontCompareToYes
question.text: Look at the code snippet below. Which description matches the result of this code?

answerItem.text: BOOL is a typedef for a signed char and YES is a defined constant with value 1, the comparison checks 1 == 5 and therefore evaluates to false, "entry is not checked" is the output
the output is "entry is checked" as 5 is a positive value and non-zero values evaluate to true
each assignment to a variable of type BOOL is a checked assignment like: BOOL checkedEntry = 5?YES:NO; the output is "entry is checked"
BOOL is internally handled as the C99 type _Bool, therefore the compiler converts 5 to true(1)

question.name: rulesOfThumbBool
question.text: What are the rules of thumb dealing with type BOOL?

answerItem.text: be carefully to compare to YES or NO directly if you can not guarantee, that the value to compare with is actually YES or NO assigned to
assign YES or NO to variables of type BOOL and no other values(or return values of expressions)

question.name: dynamicBinding
question.text: Look at the options below. Which options matches the meaning of Dynamic Binding?

answerItem.text: determining the method to invoke at runtime instead of at compile time
is also referred to as late binding
in Objective-C, all methods are resolved dynamically at runtime
the exact code executed is determined by both the method name (the selector) and the receiving object
is a key concept in providing a consistent programming interface to the classes in a program
to enable Dynamic Binding a base class must provide a common function which is inherit by sub-classes
functions declared in a base class or protocol can be bind at runtime only

question.name: nilIsAnObject
question.text: What is the output of the program?

answerItem.text: intVar = 0, objectVar = (null)
intVar = 15, objectVar = (null)
intVar = 15, objectVar = Hello
intVar = 0, objectVar = Hello
the code does not compile
the code crashes at runtime

question.name: forwardClassDeclaration
question.title: Multiple options are correct
question.text: The code snippet makes use of forward class declaration using @class. Choose the options which matches the usage and benefit of a forward class declaration.

answerItem.text: Both classes, Person and Machine, refer to each other. The code would not compile correctly, if each class imports the other in the header file. Forward class declaration must be used.
Forward class declaration reduces interdependency of classes and keeps compile time as low as possible.
Limits the scope of what a consumer of your class needs to import and therefore supports maintenance.
Forward class declaration should be used when a class derives from a base class.
A forward class declaration is sufficient if the class uses functions from NSObject only.
The member variable, which stores a pointer to an forward declared object, cannot be inherited from derived classes.

question.name: literalSyntax
question.title: Only one option is correct
question.text: The code shown makes use of the literal syntax of Objective-C. Which option applies to the code?

answerItem.text: objects of type NSNumber can not be created using the literal syntax
this code prints: numbers: 41, 42
this code prints: numbers: 41, 42, null, 43, 44
line 14, an exception is thrown at runtime as a nil is missing at the end of the parameter list
an exception of type NSInvalidArgumentException is thrown at runtime

question.name: enumerationsSwitchStatement
question.text: The code shown produces a compiler warning. Why?

answerItem.text: The compiler warning is: Enumeration values 'MY_OPTION_2', 'MY_OPTION_3', and 'MY_OPTION_4' not handled in switch

question.name: propertiesNamingConventions
question.text: What are the naming conventions for synthesized property methods?

answerItem.text: The method used to access the value (the getter method) has the same name as the property. The getter method for a property called firstName will also be called firstName.

The method used to set the value (the setter method) starts with the word "set" and then uses the capitalized property name. The setter method for a property called firstName will be called setFirstName:.

question.name: propertiesSynthesizeDirective
question.text: Which option matches the usage of the @synthesize directive?

answerItem.text: the @synthesize directive is used to give the generated instance variable a specified name e.g. @synthesize firstName = foreName
the @synthesize directive must be used for every property declared
the @synthesize directive must be used for every property which uses memory-management relevant attributes like strong, weak, copy and assign
the @synthesize directive must not be used for readonly properties

question.name: propertiesMemoryAttrDefault
question.text: Which is the default memory-management related attribute for properties?

answerItem.text: strong
Strong

question.name: propertiesMemoryAttr
question.text: What does the program print?

answerItem.text: firstName=Paul, printing the nickName crashes with an EXC_BAD_ACCESS exception
firstName=Paul, lastName=Johnson, nickName=paul
firstName=Paul, lastName=Johnson
firstName=Paul
prints nothing and trying to print the nickName crashes with an EXC_BAD_ACCESS exception

question.name: propertiesAttrAdhereSemantics
question.text: What does the program print?

answerItem.text: firstName=Paul, lastName=1234567
firstName=Paul, lastName=Johnson
firstName=1234, lastName=1234567
firstName=1234, lastName=Johnson

question.name: equalObjects
question.title: Object Equality
question.text: Which options best matches the handling of object equality?

answerItem.text: Provide isEqual: and hash methods for objects that you will want to check for equality.
Objects that are equal must have the same hash, but objects that have the same hash do not necessarily have to be equal.
Testing every property to determine equality is not necessary, check what is useful.
Write hash methods that will be quick but provide a reasonably low level of collisions.
Objects that have the same hash must be equal.
Objects that are equal must have the same identity, obj1 == obj2 must be true.
The isEqual: method from NSObject is sufficient.

question.name: implementingInit
question.title: Implementing an Initializer
question.text: There are several critical rules to follow when implementing an init... method that serves as a class’s sole initializer. Order the required steps!

answerItem.text: Invoke the superclass (super) initializer.
Check the object returned by the superclass. If it is nil, then initialization cannot proceed; return nil to the receiver.
When initializing instance variables that are references to objects, retain or copy the object as necessary (in memory-managed code).

After setting instance variables to valid initial values, return self unless:A problem prevented initialization from succeeding, in which case return nil - or - It was necessary to return a substituted object, in which case release the freshly allocated object first (in memory-managed code).

question.name: designatedInitializer
question.title: Designated Initializer
question.text: What are the rules of thumb regarding a designated initializer?

answerItem.text: Document which one it is. All other initializer should call through to this one!
If the designated initializer is different from the superclass, ensure that its designated initializer is overridden.
Throw an exception in initializers overridden from superclasses that should not be used in the subclass.

question.name: errorModel
question.title: ARC and Exceptions
question.text: What does the program print?

answerItem.text: the program prints: Person:0x1027176b0 - Sarah Johnson, Person:0x102717050 - Paul Johnson, Person:0x102711240 - Paul Johnson, finally
the program prints: the reason..., finally
the program prints: finally
the program prints: the reason...

question.name: nscopyProtocol
question.title: Copying protocols
question.text: What are the rules of thumb implementing the NSCopying or NSMutableCopying protocols?

answerItem.text: Implement NSCopying if yout object will need no be copied.
If your object has mutable and immutable variants, implement both the NSCopying and NSMutableCopying protocols.
Decide whether a copy will be shallow or deep, and prefer shallow, where possible, for a normal copy.
Consider adding a deep-copy method if deep copies of yout object will be useful.

question.name: delegates
question.title: Delegates
question.text: Which are the general steps implementing a delegate for a custom class?

answerItem.text: Declare the delegate accessor methods in your class header file e.g. -(void)setDelegate: and -(id)delegate
Implement the accessor methods. If you use ARC, the instance variable which holds the reference to the delegate should be __weak to avoid retain circles.

Declare a formal or informal protocol containing the programmatic interface for the delegate. Informal protocols are categories on the NSObject class. If you declare a formal protocol for your delegate, make sure you mark groups of optional methods with the @optional directive.
You should always pass the instance that is delegating through your interface methods e.g. -(void)dataLoader:(DataLoader*)loader didLoadData:(NSData*)data
Before invoking a delegation method, make sure the delegate implements it by sending it a respondsToSelector: message.

question.name: categories
question.title: Categories
question.text: Which options describe a category?

answerItem.text: A category can be declared for any class, even if you don’t have the original implementation source code.
Any methods that you declare in a category will be available to all instances of the original class.
Any methods that you declare in a category will be available to all subclasses of the original class.
At runtime, there’s no difference between a method added by a category and one that is implemented by the original class.
A category must be declared and implemented in separate files (own .h / .m).
A category should implement private methods only.
Categories can be used to declare instance methods and are usually used for declaring additional properties.

question.name: classExtension
question.title: Class Extensions
question.text: Which options describe a class extension?

answerItem.text: A class extension can only be added to a class for which you have the source code at compile time (the class is compiled at the same time as the class extension).
The methods declared by a class extension are implemented in the @implementation block for the original class.
Unlike regular categories, a class extension can add its own properties and instance variables to a class.
Class extensions are often used to extend the public interface with additional private methods or properties for use within the implementation of the class itself.
Because no name is given in the parentheses, class extensions are often referred to as anonymous categories.
Unlike regular categories, a class extension can not add its own properties ans instance variables to a class.

section.text: Type BOOL is a typedef for a signed char and can hold any value from -128 through 127.
YES is Objective-C’s truth value, a defined constant with value 1.
As this fact can cause subtle problems, the rules of thumbs dealing with type BOOL are:
Dynamic binding can be described as:
The following example illustrates how dynamic binding can be used in Objective-C:

A nil value is the safest way to initialize an object pointer if you don’t have another value to use, because it’s perfectly acceptable in Objective-C to send a message to nil. If you do send a message to nil, obviously nothing happens.

If you expect a return value from a message sent to nil, the return value will be nil for object return types, 0 for numeric types, and NO for BOOL types. Returned structures have all members initialized to zero.

An “Objective-C Literal” is a chunk of code that references a specific Cocoa object, creating it if necessary. Using the literal syntax reduces source code size and makes it much easier to read. The code below shows how to create objects of type NSString, NSNumber, NSArray and NSDictionary using the literal syntax.
Attempting to insert nil into an array or dictionary with literal syntax will cause an exception to be thrown.

Enumerations give values are readable name. They can be used to define states, error status or options passed to methods. Enumerations can be defined with an explicit type. Doing so means that the type is guaranteed to be the chosen rather than a type chosen by the compiler. The code below illustrates the usage of enumerations.

Objective-C properties offer a way to define the information that a class is intended to encapsulate. You access or set an object’s properties via accessor methods. By default, these accessor methods are synthesized automatically for you by the compiler, so you don’t need to do anything other than declare the property using @property in the class interface. The synthesized methods follow specific naming conventions:
As well as making explicit accessor method calls, Objective-C offers an alternative dot syntax to access an object’s properties.

How the compiler should synthesize the relevant accessor methods are further specified by property attributes. In the case of attribute: readonly, the compiler will synthesize a fullName getter method, but not a setFullName: method.

By default, a readwrite property will be backed by an instance variable, which will again be synthesized automatically by the compiler. Unless you specify otherwise, the synthesized instance variable has the same name as the property, but with an underscore prefix. For a property called firstName, for example, the synthesized instance variable will be called _firstName.

Properties encapsulate data, and that data needs to have concrete ownership semantics. This affects only the setter. When the compiler synthesizes the accessors, it uses property attributes to determine what code to generate. If you create your own accessors, you must stick to what you specify for this attribute. Memory-Management related attribues are:

section.title: assign
section.text: The generated setter is a simple assign operation used for scalar types such NSInteger

section.title: strong
section.text: The new value set is retained, the old value is released (if there are no references to the object anymore). Object properties are strong by default.

section.title: weak
section.text: Defines a nonowning relationship. The new value set is not retained nor is the old value released. When the value is destroyed the property values is nilled out.

section.title: unsafe_unretained
section.text: Has the same semantics as assign but is used for objects. The value is not nilled out if the target is destroyed.

section.title: copy
section.text: Instead of retaining the value is copied.

Ensure that anywhere a property's backing variable is set, the declared semantics are adhered to. If you declare a property as copy for example ensure that this documented contract is implemented in all methods which set the property's variable like initializers or setters.
By default the compiler generates the right semantic for setters for you. Look at the program below.
The program prints:firstName=Paul, lastName=1234567
as the setter for property lastName does not implement the copy as documented with the declaration.

The hash and isEqual: methods, both declared by the NSObject protocol, are closely related. The hash method must be implemented to return an integer that can be used as a table address in a hash table structure. If two objects are equal (as determined by the isEqual: method), they must have the same hash value. If your object could be included in collections such as NSSet objects, you need to define hash and verify the invariant that if two objects are equal, they return the same hash value. The default NSObject implementation of isEqual: simply checks for pointer equality.
The general rules using isEqual: and hash are:
The program below shows the implementation of isEqual: and hash exemplary.
The program prints: 1. equal, 2. equal and 4. equal

Often initialization depends on external data to set an object to a reasonable initial state. Thus initializers can take one or more parameters; the only requirement is that the initializing method begins with the letters “init”.
A typical implementation of a initializer involves the follwing steps:

section.title: Designated Initializer
section.text: If there are multiple initializers for a class, such a class should have a designated initializer. The rules of thumb using a designated initializer are:

Automatic Reference Counting(ARC) is not exception safe by default, any objects that should be released at the end of a scope in which an exception is thrown will not be released using ARC. The program below prints: the reason..., finally
The dealloc methods are not called!
The rules of thumb handling erros in Objective-C are:
Use exceptions only for fatal errors that should bring down the entire application.
For nonfatal errors, either provide a delegate method to handle errors or offer an out-parameter NSError object.

A delegate is an object that acts on behalf of, or in coordination with, another object when that object encounters an event in a program. To implement a delegate for your custom class, complete the following steps:

explanation.name: categories
explanation.title: Categories Add Methods to Existing Classes

section.text: If you need to add a method to an existing class, perhaps to add functionality to make it easier to do something in your own application, the easiest way is to use a category.
A Category can be described as:
The code below shows a category Friendship for the class Person.

Categories can be used to declare either instance methods or class methods but are not usually suitable for declaring additional properties. It’s valid syntax to include a property declaration in a category interface, but it’s not possible to declare an additional instance variable in a category. This means the compiler won’t synthesize any instance variable, nor will it synthesize any property accessor methods. You can write your own accessor methods in the category implementation, but you won’t be able to keep track of a value for that property unless it’s already stored by the original class.

explanation.title: Class Extensions Extend the Internal Implementation
